intro: Gypsocallis nigricans, commonly known as the black-stemmed gypsocallis, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale pink. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments and has a rhizomatous root system. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, often forming dense clumps. Due to its unique appearance and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and specialized species in its native habitat.
